justification: During the prediction stage, “participants also periodically… indicated their impressions of the peer's moral character on a scale ranging from 0 (nasty) to 1 (nice).”

measured_by: 7-point Likert agreement ratings to goal statements
justification: In the goal-inference stage, “Participants evaluated the extent to which they agreed… on a 7-point Likert scale (1 = strongly disagree… 7 = strongly agree)” with statements describing the peer’s money-maximizing vs. shock-minimizing goals.

measured_by: harm aversion parameter κ estimated from utility model
justification: “The harm aversion parameter κ in this model characterizes the relative weights of the differences in money (∆m) and shocks (∆s)… A decider’s harm aversion parameter (κ) is equivalent to the decider's indifference point.”
Subjective similarity was assessed with the question: “How similar do you feel to [peer’s initials]?; continuous scale ranging from 0 = not at all similar to 100 = very similar.”
At debrief, participants were asked, “To what extent did you choose differently after you observed [peer] compared with before?” on a 0 (not at all) – 100 (very much) continuous analog scale.

measured_by: Composite of kindness, morality, reversed-selfishness ratings (0–100)
justification: Post-task, “ratings of kindness, morality, and (reversed) selfishness [were] combined into a ‘morality’ measure (Cronbach’s α = 0.93)” collected on 0–100 visual analog scales.

measured_by: Composite of competence and intelligence ratings (0–100)
justification: The authors note that “We combined ratings of competence and intelligence into a ‘competence’ measure (Cronbach’s α = 0.89)” using the same 0–100 scales.

measured_by: Composite of liking and admiration ratings (0–100)
justification: “Ratings of liking and admiration [were] combined into an ‘attitude’ measure (Cronbach’s α = 0.80)” collected on 0–100 scales.
Participants “evaluated the unpleasantness of the shocks to themselves… on a scale from 1 (not unpleasant at all) to 7 (extremely unpleasant).”
The same item asked for “unpleasantness… to the receiver on a scale from 1 (not unpleasant at all) to 7 (extremely unpleasant).”
The personality battery included “Psychopathy” as one of the “online personality questionnaires” completed before the lab session.
The pre-session battery listed “Social Desirability” among the questionnaires administered.
Participants completed the “Trait Anxiety Scale” as part of the online questionnaire battery.
The battery included an “Emotion Regulation” questionnaire prior to laboratory testing.
The list of questionnaires specifies the “Interpersonal Reactivity Index.”
The personality measures included the “Moral Identity Scale.”
Participants completed the “Oxford Utilitarianism Scale” as part of the personality battery.
